name: Casse-Croûte (Bermondsey Street)
short_title: A tiny, transportive French bistro near London Bridge
summary: Casse-Croûte is a tiny, candlelit French bistro on Bermondsey Street that regulars describe as “like being in France.” The menu is short and changes daily (often chalkboard-written and in French), focusing on classic, rich French cooking with generous portions. Expect confident wine recommendations, attentive service, and an intimate, close-quarters dining room ideal for a treat meal, date night, or long lunch.
what_diners_love: Authentic French flavours that feel genuinely “Paris”
Daily-changing seasonal menu with thoughtful cooking and quality ingredients
Rich, indulgent classics done well and often beautifully presented
Wine pairings and French aperitifs (kir/kir royale frequently praised)
Staff who translate/explain the French menu and recommend dishes confidently
popular_dishes: Boeuf en croûte / Beef Wellington (signature dish)
Rabbit dishes (stuffed rabbit; rabbit with mustard sauce)
atmosphere_experience: A small, bustling bistro with a distinctly French feel—often with French spoken on the floor and a menu that may need quick translation. It’s charming and intimate, but tables are close and it can feel loud or cramped when busy. Many diners recommend leaning into the slower rhythm: linger over courses, share plates, and enjoy the full bistro experience.
good_to_know: Menu is short and meat-forward; vegetarian options can be limited depending on the day
Booking strongly recommended; walk-ins sometimes possible at the bar but not reliable
Service style varies: usually attentive and friendly, though some find it more formal/impersonal
Portions are generous; cooking can be rich/heavily seasoned (some mention saltiness on certain dishes)
Often a special-occasion spend; wine can feel pricey to some diners
Very small space: tight seating and can be noisy at peak times
Accessibility concerns noted (at least one reviewer says it’s not suitable for wheelchairs)
best_for: Anyone chasing a “Paris in London” bistro vibe
top_tip: Go in with an open mind since the menu changes daily. If sharing, many diners suggest multiple starters + one main + dessert between two people to taste more of the menu.
